qas.question: What can be seen as of essential importance to a practiced of humanism?
What is a common tenant of humanism?
These days humanism could be viewed as a form of what?
What can be credited for the changes in the definition of humanism?
Instead of turning to a spiritual or divine source practicers of humanism turn to what?
What can be seen as no importance to the practice of humanism?
What is a fake tenant of humanism?
What is humanism no longer viewed as a form of?
What had no influence on the changes in the definition of humanism?
What does humanism condemn instead of turning to a spiritual or divine source?

context: Humanism is a philosophical and ethical stance that emphasizes the value and agency of <a0_0><b5_0>human beings<b5_0/><a0_0/>, individually and collectively, and generally prefers critical thinking and evidence (rationalism, empiricism) over acceptance of dogma or superstition. The meaning of the term humanism has fluctuated according to the successive <a3_0><b8_0>intellectual movements<b8_0/><a3_0/> which have identified with it. Generally, however, humanism refers to a perspective that affirms some notion of human <a1_0><b6_0>freedom and progress<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In modern times, humanist movements are typically aligned with <a2_0><b7_0>secularism<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and today humanism typically refers to a non-theistic life stance centred on human agency and looking to <a4_0><b9_0>science<b9_0/><a4_0/> rather than revelation from a supernatural source to understand the world.
